publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
description: A voluntary framework to manage and reduce cybersecurity risks. Expanded to include Governance as a core function and apply to all sectors, not just critical infrastructure.
coverage: Governance, Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover functions; Risk Assessment; Improvement
applicable_areas: All sizes and sectors globally, Critical Infrastructure, Federal Agencies (voluntary)

publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
description: Focused on improving critical infrastructure cybersecurity. Core functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover.
coverage: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover functions; Supply Chain Risk Management
applicable_areas: Critical Infrastructure (original focus), widely adopted across all sectors.

description: Specifies the requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an Information Security Management System (ISMS).
coverage: Management System Requirements, Information Security Controls (Annex A), CIA Triad
applicable_areas: Global, all types and sizes of organizations seeking certification.

description: The former standard for the ISMS. Annex A controls updated and restructured in the 2022 revision.
coverage: Management System Requirements, 14 Domains of Controls
applicable_areas: Global, all types and sizes of organizations (now superseded for certification).

publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
description: A seven-step, disciplined, and structured process (Prepare, Categorize, Select, Implement, Assess, Authorize, Monitor) for managing security and privacy risk throughout the system lifecycle.
coverage: Enterprise Risk Management, System Authorization (ATO), Security, Privacy, and Supply Chain Risk
applicable_areas: US Federal Agencies (mandatory), Defense Contractors, highly regulated industries.

publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
description: Six-step RMF lifecycle (Prepare step was added in Rev. 2). Focused heavily on C&A (Certification and Accreditation).
coverage: System Authorization, Security Controls, Lifecycle Management
applicable_areas: US Federal Agencies, highly regulated sectors.

description: A privacy extension to ISO/IEC 27001. Provides requirements and guidance for implementing, maintaining, and continually improving a PIMS, including controls for PII controllers and processors.
coverage: Privacy Principles, PII Management, Consent, Data Subject Rights, Controller/Processor specific controls
applicable_areas: Organizations globally subject to data protection laws (e.g., GDPR, CCPA) that are PII Controllers or Processors.

publisher: ISACA (Information Systems Audit and Control Association)
description: A business framework for the Governance and Management of Enterprise IT (EGIT). Focuses on creating value through I&T. Includes design factors to tailor governance systems.
coverage: Enterprise Governance, Audit, Risk Management, Security, Performance Management, Alignment
applicable_areas: Enterprise-level, all industries, IT Governance and Management.

publisher: ISACA (Information Systems Audit and Control Association)
description: Integrated five COBIT 4.1 areas (governance, risk, security, value, assurance) into a single framework. Introduced the 5 Principles and 7 Enablers.
coverage: IT Governance, Risk Management, Assurance, Value Creation

description: A cloud security control framework covering 17 domains. It provides a baseline set of security controls and guidance to assess the overall security risk of a cloud service.
coverage: Technical Controls, Cloud Security Architecture, Governance, Compliance Mapping, Risk
applicable_areas: Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), Cloud Customers (CSCs), and third-party auditors.

description: Older version focusing on 13 domains. Used for self-assessment and compliance mapping prior to the CCM v4 update.
coverage: Cloud Security Controls, Compliance and Audit

description: Provides principles and generic guidelines on managing risk. Non-certifiable standard that promotes the integration of risk management into all organizational activities and decision-making.
coverage: Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) Principles, Framework, and Process
applicable_areas: Global, all types of organizations for any type of risk (strategic, financial, operational, security).

description: The first edition of the standard. Revised in 2018 for clarity, conciseness, and greater emphasis on top management leadership and integration.
coverage: Risk Management Principles, Framework, and Process

publisher: COSO (Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission)
description: Highlights the importance of considering risk in both the strategy-setting process and in driving performance, based on five interrelated components (Governance and Culture, Strategy and Objective-Setting, Performance, Review and Revision, Information, Communication, and Reporting).
coverage: Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) for Strategic and Performance Focus, Internal Control
applicable_areas: Enterprise-level, focus on financial services, public companies, and internal control over financial reporting (ICFR).

publisher: COSO (Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission)
description: The original ERM framework. Structured around 8 components. Less focus on strategy and performance alignment than the 2017 revision.
coverage: Enterprise Risk Management for Internal Control

full_name: Operationally Critical Threat, Asset, and Vulnerability Evaluation
publisher: Carnegie Mellon University Software Engineering Institute (SEI)
description: A comprehensive, self-directed methodology that focuses on information assets and their containers to manage information security risks. Streamlined for faster, more repeatable assessments.
coverage: Information Asset-Centric Risk Assessment, Threat Scenarios, Qualitative Risk Analysis
applicable_areas: Small and Medium Organizations (SMOs), organizations seeking a qualitative and repeatable risk assessment method.

full_name: Operationally Critical Threat, Asset, and Vulnerability Evaluation
publisher: Carnegie Mellon University Software Engineering Institute (SEI)
description: A version of OCTAVE geared specifically toward smaller organizations (under 100 people) that have simple or flat organizational structures.
